output.rationale: This is an original epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 (and PM10) exposure and hospital admissions for respiratory diseases including asthma and COPD. It uses distributed lag non-linear models, which is consistent with time-series methodology. The abstract indicates statistical significance testing and refers to 'admission risk' and associations, suggesting quantitative effect estimates are reported. While the focus on COVID-19 periods is a specific context, it meets the core inclusion criteria of PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, and appropriate study design.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and asthma exacerbations resulting in ED visits using a time-series design (daily associations with mixed-effects quasi-Poisson regression). The outcome is respiratory ED visits (asthma is a respiratory condition). While the abstract does not explicitly provide RR/OR values, it reports statistical associations (P<10-4) and describes a dose-response relationship with PM2.5 concentration, suggesting quantitative effect estimates are reported in the full text. All inclusion criteria appear to be met.

This is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. Asthma is a respiratory condition, and hospitalizations for asthma qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%). All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological research; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as the primary pollutant (62% of days) with pollutant-specific AQI results reported; (3) outcome includes both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma; (4) case-crossover design; (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals; (6) published in English. Although the primary exposure is AQI rather than PM2.5 directly, the abstract explicitly states that PM2.5-specific AQI associations were analyzed and PM2.5 was the dominant pollutant.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (along with cardiovascular). The study reports quantitative associations (positive associations mentioned for 31 of 32 respiratory outcomes), includes effect estimates with PM2.5 as the exposure, and analyzes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome. Although it examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included and analyzed separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple air pollutant exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory disease, (4) study design is explicitly stated as time-series, (5) reports RR with 95% CI for PM2.5 (1.030, 1.012-1.049), and (6) published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 exposure on respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome includes both emergency department presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis (a respiratory condition), (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with quantitative effect estimates (>10% increased risk for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. While multiple pollutants were examined (NO2, PM2.5, PM10), PM2.5 was specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) the study design is time-series, (5) quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) are reported for PM2.5, and (6) the abstract is in English. While the study also examines other pollutants (PM10, SO2, NO2), PM2.5 is one of the primary exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) the exposure is PM2.5, (3) the outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) the study design is case-crossover, (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) it is published in English. While the population is specific (childhood cancer survivors), this does not violate any exclusion criteria, and the study provides quantitative effect estimates for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure along with PM10 and NO2, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (bronchiolitis), (4) the study design is case-crossover as stated in methods, (5) odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 (1.04 [1.02-1.06]), and (6) it is published in English. None of the exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes fine particulate matter (PM2.5), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children, (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR: 1.004 [0.955-1.056] and stratified estimates), and (6) published in English. The study examines PM2.5 among other exposures and provides quantitative effect estimates.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with statistical significance, original research), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome that differs from the typical respiratory hospitalization outcomes (e.g., COPD, asthma exacerbations, pneumonia in general) that are the focus of systematic reviews examining PM2.5 and respiratory health. The review appears to target general respiratory hospitalizations, not disease-specific admissions for a particular pathogen.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for asthma, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals (e.g., PM2.5 RR=1.016, 95% CI: 1.008-1.025), and (6) published in English in a peer-reviewed journal (Environmental Health Perspectives).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design, (5) reports incidence rate ratios with 95% CIs (IRR 1.043, 95% CI: 1.000-1.089 for ED; IRR 1.013, 95% CI: 0.971-1.056 for admissions), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological time-series study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) it uses time-series design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models, (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported (e.g., relative risk and percentage increases in hospitalization risk), and (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically mentioned in the results with positive lag effects on respiratory admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure; (3) The outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations; (4) Time series analysis with GAM was used as the study design; (5) The results state that PM2.5 was 'associated with increased risks of hospitalizations' indicating effect estimates were calculated; (6) The article appears to be in English. The study examines PM10 as well, but PM2.5 is clearly one of the exposures analyzed.

This is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure (from wildfire smoke) and respiratory hospitalizations (among other cardiorespiratory outcomes). The study reports relative risks with confidence intervals. Although it examines medium-term (3-month) rather than acute exposure and includes both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, it meets all core inclusion criteria: original study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates with CIs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using a generalized additive Poisson model, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations for upper respiratory tract infections, (4) time-series design examining daily variations, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (0.84% increase, 95% CI 0.05-1.64% per 10 μg/m³ increase in PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Upper respiratory tract infections are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization, making this eligible for inclusion.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD. Although the main findings focus on NO2, the study explicitly reports risk ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 exposure in relation to respiratory hospitalizations (asthma RR: 0.981-1.148; COPD RR: 0.966-1.019). The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological research, includes PM2.5 as exposure, respiratory hospitalization as outcome, time-series design, reports effect estimates with CIs, and is published in English.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI), it uses a retrospective cohort study design rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design. The study analyzes daily county-level hospitalization rates using distributed lag models, which is characteristic of ecological time-series analysis, but is explicitly described as a 'retrospective cohort study' following individual Medicare beneficiaries. This design distinction is critical for the systematic review's specification.

Although this is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. While respiratory conditions are mentioned as secondary findings, the study's focus and main analysis target cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes, which do not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression; examines PM2.5 exposure (AQI of PM2.5); reports respiratory ED visits for pneumonia and COPD/asthma as outcomes; provides quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (RR for pneumonia: 1.071, 95% CI: 1.025-1.118); and appears to be published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it explicitly reports PM2.5 associations with respiratory ED visits.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (pneumonia) hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the study design is a prospective cohort rather than time-series or case-crossover. The inclusion criteria specifically require time-series or case-crossover designs, which this study does not meet despite using DLNM methodology.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency room visits using a time-series approach (generalized additive model with lag structure). It reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR = 1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.020). The outcome is emergency department visits for respiratory diseases including asthma, bronchitis, and COPD. The study appears to be in English and provides quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated, (5) reports percentage change in odds with 95% CI (equivalent to OR), and (6) published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 showing 1.2% increase in odds per 10 μg/m3 increase.

While this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatological condition with pulmonary manifestations, not general respiratory hospitalization. The review seeks studies on respiratory hospitalizations (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, general respiratory conditions), not autoimmune diseases affecting the lungs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study, (2) Exposure is PM2.5, (3) Outcome is respiratory emergency department visits (asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, upper respiratory infections), (4) Study design is case-crossover (time-stratified), (5) Reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) Published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using SPARCS database; (2) PM2.5 is a primary exposure; (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD; (4) uses case-crossover design explicitly stated; (5) reports excess rates with 95% CI (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%); (6) appears to be in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

Although the title mentions 'hospitalization', the abstract clearly indicates the outcome is 'outpatient visits' for upper respiratory tract infections, not hospitalizations or ED visits. The study uses a generalized additive model (time-series design) with PM2.5 exposure, but does not meet the outcome requirement of respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using Poisson regression on daily count data; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED visits and respiratory hospitalizations; (4) the study design is time-series based on daily county-level counts linked with daily PM2.5; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.25, 95% CI: 1.21, 1.30 for respiratory disease EDVs); (6) appears to be published in English. The study explicitly reports effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations in addition to ED visits.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (along with other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for AECOPD. It reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) and meets all inclusion criteria. While the study also examines temperature interactions and other pollutants (NO2, PM10), PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures with specific results reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure, measures respiratory hospital admissions as the outcome, and reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI = 0.87, 2.35%). The study is published in English and provides the required relative risk estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (source-specific PM2.5), evaluates respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits (influenza and pneumonia), and reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (excess rates). The study appears to be published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. It uses generalized additive models with quasi-Poisson regression, reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (5.302% increase, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445 per 10 μg/m³), and meets all inclusion criteria. Upper respiratory tract infection qualifies as a respiratory condition requiring emergency department visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive models, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma), (4) time-series design evident from use of generalized additive models with lag structures analyzing daily hospitalization rates, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase), and (6) published in English

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which qualifies as respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, (4) study design is time-series as explicitly stated, (5) reports a quantitative effect estimate of 7.2% (95% CI: 1.7-13.1%), and (6) published in English. Asthma is a respiratory condition and emergency room admissions are appropriate outcomes for this review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study with case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly measured as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ILD admissions are respiratory hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% CIs, and (6) published in English. While the abstract primarily emphasizes SO2 and NO2 results, PM2.5 exposure was assessed and the study examines air pollutants and respiratory hospitalizations.

While this is a time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the abstract does not report the specific RR/OR for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations. Only results for NO2, ozone, and noise are presented in the results section. Without the PM2.5-specific effect estimate for respiratory outcomes in the abstract, we cannot confirm this study meets the inclusion criteria requirement of reporting a quantitative effect measure for the exposure-outcome pair of interest.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (generalized additive model with distributed lag models) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (COPD admissions). The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in daily admissions). While the abstract only provides percentage increases rather than explicit RR/OR with confidence intervals, the methodology and results section indicate these estimates were calculated, which is typical for time-series studies.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure (also examines PM2.5-10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.73% increase with 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original ecological time-series study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and asthma), (4) study design is time-series, (5) reports relative risks with values (RR = 1.017, 1.022, 1.020 at different lags), and (6) published in English. All elements are clearly stated in the abstract.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions with RR and 95% CI reported. However, the study design is difference-in-differences with distributed lag non-linear models, which is not a traditional time-series or case-crossover design as specified in inclusion criteria. While it uses daily time-series data and examines short-term exposure effects similar to time-series studies, the difference-in-differences approach is methodologically distinct. This requires expert judgment on whether the modified analytical approach is acceptable for the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for COPD and acute upper respiratory diseases, (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) the abstract reports positive associations (effect estimates) for PM2.5 with various lag periods, suggesting quantitative measures were calculated, and (6) published in English. While the abstract does not explicitly show the numerical effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly states 'positive results were observed' for PM2.5 associations, indicating such estimates exist in the full paper.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory infections including pneumonia, COPD, bronchitis). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (percentage increases in hospitalizations per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5). The abstract is in English and contains all necessary information.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and multiple hospital admission outcomes including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations among other disease categories. All inclusion criteria are met: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly studied, (3) respiratory hospitalizations included as one of the outcomes, (4) time-series design using quasi-Poisson regression, (5) reports effect estimates with 95% CI (e.g., percent increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive model of Poisson regression, (2) exposure includes PM2.5 as one of the analyzed pollutants, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room visits which are respiratory ED visits, (4) time-series design is explicitly used with daily counts, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 effects, and (6) published in English. Although the study also examines PM2.5-bound PAHs, PM2.5 itself is analyzed separately and the inclusion criteria allow studies with PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) time-series design clearly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (e.g., PM2.5: 0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%), and (6) published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly measured and analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv), which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) time-series study design is clearly stated, (5) reports relative risks with specific quantitative estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 results are separately reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome includes asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports associations with 95% confidence intervals mentioned in results. The study analyzes PM2.5 among other pollutants, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) includes respiratory hospitalizations as one of the outcomes with specific effect estimate (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%), (4) time-series design (GAM with daily data), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, and (6) appears to be in English. Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association is explicitly reported with effect estimates.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) and hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. The abstract mentions 'emergency admissions to hospital' and states that 'Secondary pollutants, especially nonprimary PM2.5, nitrate and sulfate, were more important for respiratory outcomes.' The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. Although the abstract primarily presents cardiovascular results, it explicitly states respiratory admissions were examined and found associations with PM2.5 components.

This is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models (GAMs), which is a time-series design. It examines PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory hospitalizations as one of the outcomes analyzed (NO2 showed 1.36% increase in respiratory hospitalizations with 95%CI). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. While it examines multiple organ systems, it does analyze and report specific results for respiratory hospitalizations, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for asthma exacerbations, (4) time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports RR with 95% CI, and (6) published in English. Asthma exacerbations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization/ED visit.

Although this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with PM2.5 controlled as a covariate, the primary exposure of interest is climate parameters (precipitation and temperature) on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. The results explicitly state that PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days. PM2.5 was adjusted for as a confounder rather than being the main exposure being investigated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI - acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis); (4) the study design is clearly time-series; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and other pollutants; (6) the abstract is in English. Although multiple pollutants are studied, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), focuses on respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design with Poisson regression; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Respiratory hospital admissions is a primary outcome; (4) Time-series design analyzing daily counts; (5) Reports pooled relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions (7.5% [4.9-10.2%]); (6) Published in English. While the study also examines ultrafine particles, PM2.5 is analyzed separately with quantitative effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) time-series study design using Poisson regression, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 for different racial/ethnic groups), and (6) published in English. The study provides clear effect estimates with confidence implied through the statistical analysis.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates (1.74% increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5 with 95% CI: 1.41-2.07%) for respiratory admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (159,365 admissions identified), (4) uses a time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.95% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory diseases, 95% CI 1.63-2.27%), and (6) published in English. Although it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly analyzed and reported.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 concentration itself. The study uses PM2.5 and PM10 as carriers to measure oxidative potential (OP_AA and OP_GSH), which is a chemical property of particles rather than PM2.5 mass concentration. The exposure does not meet inclusion criteria as it focuses on oxidative potential metrics rather than PM2.5 exposure per se.

This is an original epidemiological study examining the association between fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma in Atlanta (2002-2010). The study uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models and reports quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals). While it focuses on source-specific contributions of PM2.5 rather than total PM2.5, the exposure is still PM2.5, and asthma ED visits are a respiratory outcome meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using GAM for short-term effects, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory disease hospitalization, (4) time-series design (GAM applied to estimate short-term effects), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., 1.95% increase with 95% CI: 0.25, 3.67 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study examines both PM2.5 and PM10, but PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma). It reports risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including asthma hospitalization. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcomes, time-series design, and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) time-series design is clearly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates (excess risks) with 95% CIs are reported for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory healthcare visits (which include hospitalizations/ED visits), reports odds ratios with quantitative effect estimates, and appears to be published in English. The study explicitly mentions analyzing 'respiratory-related healthcare visits' and reports effect estimates for PM2.5 increases associated with increased odds of healthcare encounters.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospitalization for respiratory diseases in children, (4) the study design is case-crossover, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) the article is in English. While multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other exposures) and respiratory outcomes including ED and inpatient visits for asthma exacerbation. The study reports rate ratios with confidence intervals. While the primary focus is on effect modification by viral infections and the main results presented are for pollen, the abstract states PM2.5 was analyzed and mentions trends for PM2.5 were observed, suggesting quantitative estimates are available in the full text.

This study meets the key inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis of daily data, (2) PM2.5 is included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (for patients with comorbid respiratory diseases and diabetes), (4) it appears to be a time-series study design based on GAM analysis of daily admissions, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (7.25% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5), and (6) the article appears to be in English. While the population is limited to those with diabetes comorbidity, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization which meets the criteria.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with CI), it should be excluded because the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which typically refers to conditions like common cold, pharyngitis, and sinusitis. These are different from lower respiratory tract conditions (pneumonia, COPD, asthma) that are typically the focus of respiratory hospitalization reviews. Upper respiratory tract infections are generally less severe and the focus on 'hospital visits' for AURTIs is atypical for serious respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive models, (2) exposure includes PM2.5 as one of the pollutants examined, (3) outcome is emergency department visits for asthma (a respiratory condition), (4) study design is explicitly time-series, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (e.g., 6.1% increase, CI: 2.1-10.3%), and (6) published in English. While the outcome is specifically asthma ED visits rather than all respiratory hospitalizations, asthma is a respiratory condition and ED visits are explicitly included in the review criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study using case time series analysis (a type of time-series design) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.43% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5). Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (1.6%, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English

While this study examines PM2.5 among other pollutants, uses a case-crossover design, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than hospitalization or emergency department visit. The results indicate no association was found with PM2.5. The primary focus is on ultrafine particles, not PM2.5. The outcome does not clearly meet the respiratory hospitalization/ED visit criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) Outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) Uses time-stratified case-crossover analysis, (5) Reports associations/effect estimates for PM2.5 in both single and two-pollutant models, and (6) Published in English. While the abstract doesn't explicitly state numerical effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly indicates that quantitative associations were computed and reported for PM2.5.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome is COPD hospitalization, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) study design is case-crossover (time-stratified); (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals; (6) published in English based on the abstract text

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly studied, (3) respiratory hospitalizations are among the outcomes (916,388 respiratory admissions identified), (4) case-crossover design as stated in title and methods (conditional logistic regression), (5) reports odds ratios with 95% CIs for respiratory admissions (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5), (6) appears to be in English. The study examines multiple outcomes (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory) but respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included with quantitative estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using Quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model, suggesting a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions for asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis; (4) the study design is time-series based on the methods described (analyzing short-term effects with control for trend, seasonality, and temporal factors); (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported as relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions; (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5-specific results for respiratory hospitalizations are clearly reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports hospital admissions for pneumonia (a respiratory outcome), and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (12% and 4% increases in admissions).

The primary exposure is coarse particles (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5. While the study mentions PM2.5 as an adjustment variable and for comparison purposes, the main focus is on coarse particles and their association with respiratory ED visits. This does not meet inclusion criterion #2 which specifically requires PM2.5 as the exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure with quantitative results, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions), (4) time-series study design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3), and (6) appears to be published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization relevant to the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 exposure (alongside PM10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for COPD exacerbation, (4) time-series study design using Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risks with statistical significance, and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization/ED visit.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency department visits, with quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with 95% credible intervals) reported. Although it also examines ozone, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5 from various sources, (3) outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports excess risk (equivalent to RR) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including asthma, and (6) appears to be published in English. Though it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it does report on respiratory ED visits which is the outcome of interest.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study that examines PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The study uses generalized additive models to assess associations and reports effect estimates (positive and significant impacts mentioned, attributable risks calculated). Asthma hospitalizations are a respiratory hospitalization outcome. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure included, respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, and effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series regression with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) the article is in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures studied; (3) The outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) It uses a time-series study design; (5) It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 increase, 95% CI 0.21-2.26%); (6) The article appears to be published in English based on the abstract provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma emergency department visits which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports rate ratios (RRs) with effect estimates mentioned, (6) published in English. While PM2.5 is analyzed alongside other pollutants, this is acceptable per the inclusion criteria.

While the study includes PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one exposure and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome using a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson regression with lags), the abstract only reports quantitative effect estimates for temperature (18% increase in risk for 4°C temperature increase), not for PM2.5. The primary focus is on temperature effects. Without a reported effect estimate for PM2.5, this does not meet inclusion criterion 5 for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (and ozone) and cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative risk ratios for respiratory disease outcomes (e.g., RR=1.020 for respiratory disease-ozone in ED visits). While the study includes both ozone and PM2.5, PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed. The outcomes include respiratory disease and asthma/wheeze for both ED visits and hospital admissions, meeting the outcome criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study with case time series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits among other outcomes, (4) time-series design, (5) reports excess relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (1.34% for respiratory ED visits), and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular and natural causes, it specifically analyzes respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design with time-series methods; PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as an exposure (among other pollutants); the outcome is respiratory hospitalization due to COPD exacerbations; quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios) with 95% CIs are reported for PM2.5 (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.006-1.055 per 10 μg/m3); and it appears to be published in English.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions (among other outcomes). The study explicitly states it analyzed 'Medicare respiratory and cardiovascular hospital admissions' using time-series methods with generalized linear models. The results section indicates significant associations were found and effect estimates were calculated (comparing distributed-lag vs single-day effects). The study meets all inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, time-series design, and appears to report quantitative effect measures.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with distributed lag, indicating a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for pediatric asthma, which is a respiratory ED visit; (4) the study design is time-series based on the methodology described; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with relative risks and 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.021 for PM2.5); (6) the article is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed with reported effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with case-crossover design as indicated in the title; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) The outcome is hospital admission for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) The study design is time-series/case-crossover; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported (rate ratios with 95% CI for PM2.5: 1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028); (6) The article is in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included with its own effect estimate.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI including pneumonia and bronchiolitis), (4) time-series study design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 was specifically analyzed and reported.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma-related hospitalizations). The study uses time-series methodology with Poisson regression, reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals, and focuses on cardiopulmonary (including respiratory) hospitalizations. Although it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory outcomes which meet the inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department visits in children. While the study found no significant association between PM2.5 and ER admissions, it meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with Poisson regression, examines PM2.5 as one of the exposures, respiratory ED visits as the outcome, and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. The fact that PM2.5 showed null results does not exclude it from a systematic review, as null findings are important to include to avoid publication bias.

While this is an interrupted time series study examining PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory hospitalizations among outcomes, it fails to meet key inclusion criteria. The study design is interrupted time series (examining long-term effects over 8 years post-fire) rather than the specified time-series or case-crossover designs that examine short-term associations. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly report specific quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, or CI) for the respiratory outcome specifically. The study appears focused on multiple outcomes (mental health, injury, cardiovascular, respiratory) and long-term disaster impacts rather than the acute PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization relationship typically examined in time-series studies.

This is an original 18-year time-series study examining PM2.5 (including speciated organic carbon fraction) exposure in relation to respiratory ED visits (bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, URI) in children. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 4% increase for URI, 8% increase for pneumonia per IQR increase). Meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), respiratory ED visits as outcome, time-series design using Poisson generalized linear models, and reports rate ratios with confidence intervals.

This study examines pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis (cardiovascular/thromboembolic outcomes), not respiratory hospitalizations. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. While it uses appropriate time-series design and reports effect estimates, it fails to meet the core inclusion criteria for outcome type and PM2.5 exposure.
The outcome is suicide death, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a critical review of PM10-mortality time-series studies, not an original epidemiological study. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not an original study, (2) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, and (3) the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit.

This is a review/systematic review of published studies (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. It fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining mortality outcomes (not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits). The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. Fails multiple inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrests (OHCA) of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on cardiovascular outcomes rather than respiratory outcomes required for inclusion.

This is an animal study (mice) investigating mechanisms of PM2.5-induced lung injury, not an epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits in humans. It does not use time-series or case-crossover design, does not report RR/OR for hospitalizations, and focuses on biological mechanisms rather than clinical outcomes.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects'), not an original epidemiological study. It discusses historical backgrounds, physicochemical characteristics, and pathological roles of PM, but does not report original data or quantitative effect estimates from a time-series or case-crossover study.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) as the exposure, not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm). While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet inclusion criteria, the exposure does not match the required PM2.5 specification. PM10 and PM2.5 are distinct particle size fractions with different health effects.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis of PM2.5 constituents and reports effect estimates, the primary outcome reported is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract specifically mentions 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the outcome with statistically significant findings. Although the study meets several inclusion criteria (original research, time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, has effect estimates), it fails the critical outcome criterion.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as the exposure. While the study is an original time-series analysis that reports effect estimates for hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes, it does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the exposure variable.

The study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm), as the particulate matter exposure. While it is a case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95%CI), the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm). The inclusion criteria specifically require PM2.5 exposure, and PM10 is a different, larger particle size fraction that does not meet this requirement.

This appears to be a health impact assessment/policy evaluation study that used relative risks from a literature review rather than an original epidemiological study that derived its own effect estimates from primary data analysis. The abstract states 'A literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and 'public health gains were calculated based on the selected relative risks', indicating this is a modeling study applying previously published RRs rather than conducting original time-series analysis. It does not meet criterion 1 for being an original epidemiological study.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits specifically. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the primary outcome and reported effect estimate is for non-traumatic diseases overall, and the respiratory-specific results did not reach statistical significance and no specific effect estimate for respiratory outcomes is provided.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome.

This study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 µm) exposure and cardiovascular events, not PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. The outcome is cardiovascular events (ICD-9: 390-459), not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory).

The outcome is cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines cardiovascular deaths rather than respiratory hospitalizations, which does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The abstract explicitly describes it as a 'systematic review' that 'included 196 articles in quantitative analysis.' Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/book chapter summarizing existing literature on air pollution and mortality, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits), and no original quantitative effect estimates are reported.

Although this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI) mortality, which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 as an exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring respiratory outcomes.

The study examines exposure to PM10 (coarse particulate matter), not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). Additionally, the outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study design is case-crossover which meets that criterion, but the exposure and outcome do not match the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series analysis with respiratory hospitalizations as outcome and effect estimates reported, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The abstract explicitly states 'Particulate matter of 10 microns in diameter or smaller (PM10)' with no mention of PM2.5 being measured or analyzed. The study examines the effect of a vegetation fire ban rather than directly assessing the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes.

The outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The exposure is primarily coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5), not PM2.5, though PM2.5 was included as an adjustment variable. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome type.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines cause-specific mortality as the health outcome, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.

This is a systematic literature review, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the review mentions that some of the reviewed articles considered PM2.5 as a risk factor, this publication itself is a review paper synthesizing evidence from 34 other studies.

This study fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5 - the title and abstract clearly state PM10 throughout; (2) The outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits - the abstract specifically states 'daily counts of natural, cardiovascular, and respiratory deaths' as the main outcome measure.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits). Both the exposure type and outcome do not meet inclusion criteria.

The study examines PM10 exposure, not PM2.5, which is the specified exposure of interest. Additionally, the outcome is years of life lost (YLL) due to respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study design is time-series and reports quantitative effect estimates, but fails to meet the critical inclusion criteria for exposure type and outcome.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While it does include PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates, the study design (systematic review/meta-analysis) disqualifies it.

While this is an original epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations with appropriate study designs (Poisson regression time-series and case-crossover) and effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 and NO2, not PM2.5. PM2.5 is not mentioned anywhere in the abstract as one of the exposures analyzed. This fails to meet the PM2.5 exposure inclusion criterion.

The study examines PM10 and O3 exposure, not PM2.5. The outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. It fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it does not meet the exposure criterion (PM10, not PM2.5) and does not meet the outcome criterion (respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits). The study examines mortality as the outcome rather than hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (requires PM2.5) and outcome criterion (requires hospitalization/ED visits, not mortality).

This study fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5 as required; (2) The outcome is mortality (cause-specific deaths), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits; (3) While it uses a time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, these critical mismatches on exposure and outcome make it ineligible for a systematic review on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits). The outcome is deaths from respiratory causes, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This study should be excluded because: (1) the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits; (2) the primary exposure is particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC), not PM2.5 mass concentration. While PM10 is mentioned as a comparison pollutant, PM2.5 is not analyzed. The study examines ultrafine and fine particle number/surface area metrics rather than PM2.5 mass.

The study does not meet inclusion criteria. The exposure is PM10, NO2, and O3, not PM2.5. The outcome is mortality (cardiovascular, respiratory, and all nonaccidental deaths), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Although the study design is case-crossover and reports effect estimates, the fundamental exposure and outcome criteria are not met.
Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and mortality outcomes (not hospitalization or ED visits). Does not meet inclusion criteria for exposure type or outcome measure.
The study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and coronary heart disease hospitalization (not respiratory hospitalization). Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with PM2.5 exposure, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study focuses on economic losses due to mortality, not hospitalizations.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10) rather than PM2.5 as the primary exposure. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality outcomes (all-cause, cardiovascular, ischemic heart disease, respiratory/thoracic cancer mortality), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory diseases, the outcome is mortality (death counts and years of life lost), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design with PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality (all-cause and specific-cause including respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. Although the study meets other criteria (PM2.5 exposure, time-series and case-crossover designs, quantitative effect estimates), it must be excluded because it does not examine the outcome of interest for this systematic review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title clearly states 'rapid systematic review and comparative synthesis' and the methods describe screening 163 articles and extracting data from 14 eligible studies. This fails inclusion criterion 1, which requires original epidemiological studies and explicitly excludes reviews and meta-analyses.

Although this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), which is explicitly listed in the exclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (death), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory deaths, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the underlying studies reviewed may include PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes, this publication itself is a secondary synthesis of existing literature.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates and confidence intervals, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

The outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study examines deaths rather than hospital admissions, which does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes.

This publication describes an integrated research program containing four different studies, including time-series epidemiologic studies of PM2.5 morbidity and mortality. However, it fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) It appears to be a program summary/overview rather than a single original epidemiological study; (2) The outcomes described are general 'morbidity and mortality' rather than specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits; (3) It includes animal studies (mouse models) and in-vitro studies which are excluded; (4) The abstract does not specify whether respiratory hospitalizations were examined or report specific effect estimates with confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes.

This is a methodological comparison study (meta-analysis vs pooled analysis) rather than an original epidemiological study. The outcomes examined are mortality (deaths due to natural causes, cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and respiratory disease), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While PM2.5 is included as an exposure and time-series design is used, the study does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome type and is essentially a meta-analysis/pooled analysis rather than an original study.

The study examines ozone exposure (not PM2.5 as primary exposure) and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Although the abstract mentions results were independent of fine particulate matter, PM2.5 appears to be a covariate rather than the primary exposure of interest. The outcome is respiratory mortality, which does not meet the inclusion criterion of respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

While this is an original time-series study that includes PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is heart failure hospitalization/incidence/mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. It fails to meet inclusion criteria 1 (must be original study, not review) and 3 (outcome must be respiratory, not cardiovascular).

This is explicitly described as a review article ('have been described in this review') discussing causal associations, toxic effects and mechanisms of PM2.5. It is not an original epidemiological study and does not report specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence...'), not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes evidence from multiple studies rather than reporting original data. Reviews are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. It reviews 364 articles on climate change and neurologic health. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, which are required for inclusion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion requires original studies, and the first exclusion criterion explicitly excludes reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly a review article (states 'This present review is an insight of...') focusing on cellular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death, not an original epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not report quantitative effect estimates for clinical outcomes.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) and the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails on both inclusion criteria #1 (study type) and #3 (outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title clearly states it is a 'Systematic review and meta-analysis' and the methods describe searching databases and combining risk estimates from 59 studies using meta-analytic techniques. This violates inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes existing studies rather than presenting new empirical data. This violates inclusion criterion 1.

This is explicitly a review article (stated as 'this review article was prepared') focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not an original epidemiological study, (2) the outcome is kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, and (3) no original effect estimates are reported.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcomes reported are respiratory and cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It violates inclusion criterion #1 and meets the first exclusion criterion. Additionally, the focus is on PM2.5 constituents (black carbon, organic carbon, etc.) rather than PM2.5 mass itself, and outcomes include mortality and morbidity broadly, not specifically respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.
This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we discussed...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are excluded per the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality (death) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study examining long-term exposure, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a review article, editorial, or commentary discussing the general health effects of wildfires rather than an original epidemiological study. The abstract discusses general knowledge about wildfires and PM2.5, mentions protective measures and knowledge gaps, but does not describe any specific study methodology, data collection, or quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, CI). The language used ('A recent example...', 'knowledge gaps remain', 'Long-term research is essential') is characteristic of a narrative review or commentary rather than an original research article.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'In this review, we summarize...') focusing on toxicological mechanisms of PM2.5 on vascular endothelial cells, not an original epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not meet inclusion criteria 1, 3, 4, or 5.

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes evidence from other studies rather than an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states it used Cochrane rapid review methodology and reviewed 450 manuscripts of which 15 met inclusion criteria. This violates inclusion criterion #1 requiring original epidemiological studies and falls under the exclusion criterion for reviews and meta-analyses.
This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit.

This is explicitly a review article as stated in the title ('A review of implications for human health'). It does not present original epidemiological data, does not report specific effect estimates with confidence intervals, and does not describe a time-series or case-crossover study design. The article discusses general health impacts of PM2.5 but does not focus on hospitalizations or ED visits as specific outcomes.

This is a review article (explicitly states 'This review summarizes and discusses studies') examining the association between PM2.5 and neurological outcomes (Alzheimer's disease and dementia), not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: it is not an original epidemiological study, the outcome is neurological rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visits, and it is a review rather than a primary study.

This study fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study, and (2) the outcome is myocardial infarction (cardiovascular hospitalization), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining ocular surface diseases (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: wrong study type and wrong outcome.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'In this review') focused on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells, not respiratory hospitalizations. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for being an original epidemiological study with respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes (digestive tract, breast, prostate cancer and cancer mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the article appears to be a narrative review or commentary that 'explores' the relationship and 'proposes mitigating strategies' rather than an original epidemiological study reporting quantitative effect estimates from time-series or case-crossover analysis.

This is explicitly stated as a review article (in both title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study.
